meanings.def: to admit that you have been defeated and want to stop fighting; to allow yourself to be caught, taken prisoner, etc.
examples: The rebel soldiers were forced to surrender.
surrender to somebody He surrendered voluntarily to his enemies.
surrender yourself (to somebody) The hijackers eventually surrendered themselves to the police.
After three weeks under siege they surrendered completely.
The British formally surrendered on 31 May.

meanings.def: to give up something/somebody when you are forced to
examples: surrender something/somebody to somebody He agreed to surrender all claims to the property.
They surrendered their guns to the police.
surrender something/somebody The defendant was released to await trial but had to surrender her passport.
The dictator surrendered power to Parliament.

related: surrender to something | surrender yourself to something

meanings.def: an act of admitting that you have been defeated and want to stop fighting
examples: He raised his hands in surrender.
The division accepted the surrender of a group of some 500 rebels.
The rebels hoisted the white flag of surrender.
The rebels were offered easy terms of surrender.
The villagers were starved into surrender.

meanings.def: the fact of allowing yourself to be controlled by something
examples: They accused the government of a surrender to business interests.

meanings.def: an act of giving something to somebody else even though you do not want to, especially after a battle, etc.
examples: They insisted on the immediate surrender of all weapons.
